articles.headline: As Banks Retreat, Private Equity Rushes to Buy Troubled Home Mortgages
articles.snippet: With banks less willing to tackle distressed home loans, private equity and hedge funds have surged into the market. Critics say the new players are too quick to foreclose.
articles.abstract: With banks less willing to tackle distressed home loans, private equity and hedge funds have surged into the market. Critics say the new players are too quick to foreclose.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity and hedge fund firms have bought more than 100,000 troubled mortgages at a discount from banks and federal housing agencies, emerging as aggressive liquidators for the remains of the mortgage crisis that erupted nearly a decade ago.

articles.headline: How Many Deaths Did Volkswagen’s Deception Cause in the U.S.?
articles.snippet: Public health researchers have formulas to calculate the lives lost from excess pollution.
articles.abstract: Public health researchers have formulas to calculate the lives lost from excess pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s diesel deception unleashed tons of extra pollutants in the United States, pollutants that can harm human health. So while many commentators have been quick to say that the cheating engines are not a highway safety concern, safety — as in health — is still an issue.
articles.byline: By Margot Sanger-Katz and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Volkswagen Scandal Highlights European Stalling on New Emissions Tests
articles.snippet: The powerful automobile industry has blocked the introduction of tests that can better measure pollution, legislators and researchers say.
articles.abstract: The powerful automobile industry has blocked the introduction of tests that can better measure pollution, legislators and researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European legislators got a jolt this month in their long-running effort to update auto-emissions standards when a German member of the European Parliament suddenly proposed exempting a whole class of vehicles.

articles.headline: As Online Data Theft Escalates, Banks Look to Retailers to Bear the Losses
articles.snippet: As a deadline approaches for new chip-enabled credit and debit cards to thwart data breaches, banks and credit unions are applying another sort of pressure by suing retailers over lax security.
articles.abstract: As a deadline approaches for new chip-enabled credit and debit cards to thwart data breaches, banks and credit unions are applying another sort of pressure by suing retailers over lax security.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 1 last year, the website Rescator, known as the “Amazon.com of the black market,” alerted its customers that huge quantities of stolen debit and credit card data would go on sale the next day.

articles.headline: Investors’ Fears on Commodities Add to Pressure on Share Prices
articles.snippet: A confluence of factors, including China’s slowing growth, falling commodity prices and trouble in the biotech sector, sent the markets lower.
articles.abstract: A confluence of factors, including China’s slowing growth, falling commodity prices and trouble in the biotech sector, sent the markets lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell sharply on Monday as investors added new fears to the list of concerns that have weighed on global markets in recent weeks.

articles.headline: Obama and Putin Play Diplomatic Poker Over Syria
articles.snippet: Presidents Obama and Vladimir V. Putin clashed at the United Nations, each trying to maneuver the other into shifting his position on the Syrian leader, Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: Presidents Obama and Vladimir V. Putin clashed at the United Nations, each trying to maneuver the other into shifting his position on the Syrian leader, Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — After circling each other for the past year, President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia squared off on Monday at the United Nations in dueling speeches that presented starkly different views on the Syrian crisis and how to bring stability to the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: The Perils of Forcing a Sale of Illiquid Assets
articles.snippet: The case of the hedge fund manager Boaz Weinstein has elicited warnings of a panic that could lead to the next financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The case of the hedge fund manager Boaz Weinstein has elicited warnings of a panic that could lead to the next financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boaz Weinstein, the hedge fund manager famous for betting against the JPMorgan Chase trader known as the “London Whale,” is being accused of his own accounting chicanery.

articles.headline: Concussions in a Required Class: Boxing at Military Academies
articles.snippet: West Point says the sport instills the courage needed for combat, but some parents and neurologists are calling for alternatives.
articles.abstract: West Point says the sport instills the courage needed for combat, but some parents and neurologists are calling for alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — A bell clanged and two cadets in boxing gloves surged from their corners in a gym at the United States Military Academy last week, throwing jabs and uppercuts while other cadets yelled, “Keep working him!” and, “Use the hook!”

articles.headline: Afghan Crisis Grows as Push to Retake Kunduz From Taliban Fails
articles.snippet: After a promised counterattack against the Taliban fell apart, the U.S. conducted at least two airstrikes to assist the government.
articles.abstract: After a promised counterattack against the Taliban fell apart, the U.S. conducted at least two airstrikes to assist the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan was plunged deeper into crisis a day after the Taliban seized the northern city of Kunduz, as the insurgents on Tuesday kept assaulting the reeling Afghan security forces and the government struggled to mount a credible response.
articles.byline: By Joseph Goldstein and Mujib Mashal
